data.title: HAPPY 82nd BIRTHDAY TO CHRIS SIMPSON ‚Äì JULY 13, 2024 ‚Äì Magna Carta
data.text:
On this page you can read comments from Magna Carta fans on Chris‚Äôs 82nd birthday.

We asked the diehard Magna Carta fans to answer these questions:

A When and where did you first see MC in concert

B What is your favorite MC song

C Your message to Chris on his 82nd Birthday

D And if you have one, please send us a photo of yourself with Chris, and perhaps other MC musicians, so that we can include them with your message.

NOTE: We didn‚Äôt edit or alter any of these messages, except when the senders asked us to do so. So any typos are as they were sent to us.

Portrait (‚ÄòChris at 70‚Äô) by the late Dutch painter and sometimes driver and tour manager Hans ‚ÄòTurf‚Äô Veen

Christopher John Simpson was born on July 13, 1942 in Harrogate in North Yorkshire, in The Yorkshire Dales.

The family then moved back to their roots in Nidderdale, also in The Yorkshire Dales.

JOHN BENNETT, Dereham, Norfolk:

A I believe it was 1969 when MC played at Camden Council‚Äôs staff social club ( I worked tlfor the council in the Health Dept). The next time I saw the band live wasn‚Äôt till 1970 in the crypt of a church in Richmond, Surrey. (Last time was Sherrington Village Hall in 2018 ‚Äì when i came with my latest wife and our daughter)

B It‚Äôs got to be Seasons, with Falkland Green second. I‚Äôve still got all the vinyls up to the mid 70s and a few from then into the 80s, but it‚Äôs the early stuff that I love.

C Have a great birthday, Chris. Just a small drop of wine and even if your vocal cords can‚Äôt hit all the octaves any more, get back to penning your wonderful lyrics tomorrow! God bless, young man! D (Never managed to get a photo, although I still have a couple of publicity shots from the late 60s which Chris allowed me to use in a trade union (Nalgo) magazine which I edited when I left Camden to work at Hillingdon Council.

First time I saw Chris was at a union exec committee (Camden Branch of Nalgo) when he was introduced prior to approval of the MC concert at the staff social club. His appearance was certainly a contrast to the typical ‚Äúsuits‚Äù on the committee ‚Äì although, to be fair, there were a few younger trendier folk there too.

EXTRA: happy to provide funny story about me gatecrashing practise at Burnsall Village Hall concert ,June 2014:

Supported Magna Carta since 1970‚Äôs , over the years travelled length & breadth of UK to see them.

In June 2014, saw they were at Burnstall Village Hall. Like me you may ask where is Burnstall VH.

Set of with sat nav & eventually found it in heart of the Dale‚Äôs.

Well, we got there early, as you do, for a good seat , to find all locked up, other than a small door at the back of the hall.

I went in , through a red velvet curtain , to make an entrance on the stage , along with the group , who were doing sound checks , well before the concert.

Not sure who got biggest fright , them or me . Chris particularly was bemused.

To this day, still awaiting an invite to join the group properly!!

ALAN ELGEY:

A: My name is Alan Elgey. I live in Cassiobury, Watford, north west of London, but originally I am from Harrogate, and went to Harrogate Grammar School, as did Chris a few years earlier.

I first saw MC play at the Harrogate Theatre in c1971/2 and also at the Royal Albert Hall in London which show is happily now a CD. Both shows were while Davy Johnstone was playing with MC. But I first heard them on disc at a music shop in Cheltenham Crescent in Harrogate (Chris might remember it). I went in there one day and the owner said: ‚ÄòHey Alan, you like Paul Simon don‚Äôt you ‚Äì I think you will like this‚Äô. And he put on an LP. I listened to it in the shop right the way through, both sides, and then bought it. I still have it and the CD version. It is ‚ÄòSeasons‚Äô and I can play every note, and hear every musical inflection in my head even now. I lost contact with what they were doing after c1975, but not with the music which I have always played on my systems, and in my mind. But through the miracle of the internet I found them again, Chris now with Linda, and Matt Barnhoorn in the early 2000s, and I have seen them as a trio playing in Bedford, Nettlebed (several times), Grassington, and with others for the ‚ÄòFarewell‚Äô concert at the Royal Dutch Theatre Carr√© in Amsterdam. I hoped for several years to see them at venues on tour in the Netherlands but sadly never made it.

B: Favorite MC song

Well there are far too many to choose. And I have ‚ÄòThe Complete Works of Magna Carta‚Äô on my desk to remind me. Of course, that book is no longer complete; can we have an updated edition to buy please? But if I must: I will pick two (or three) from my earlier memories and also from ones I discovered from the internet in this millennium. The earlier ones are from ‚ÄòSeasons‚Äô

‚Äì the spine-tingling ‚ÄòRing of Stones‚Äô which I am playing on my computer as I write this, and

‚Äì the evocative ‚ÄòTime for the Leaving‚Äô which meant so much to me as I left Harrogate in my young adult years (and which I am about to play as ‚ÄòRing of Stones finishes); this one always brings on the tears.

The ‚Äòlater‚Äô ones ‚Äì later that is in my journey ‚Äì are:

‚Äì ‚ÄòPictures in my Pillow‚Äô ‚Äì which seems to evoke special memories, now that I have children and grandchildren, which are perhaps different from those intended in the song, but nevertheless important to me

‚Äì ‚ÄòBlues for a long road home‚Äô and ‚ÄòWind on the Water‚Äô ‚Äì with Linda‚Äôs beautiful vocals, and in the case of the former, and in my memory, Lee Abbot‚Äôs fretless bass

‚Äì ‚ÄòFields of Eden‚Äô ‚Äì inevitably as it is my home as well as Chris‚Äô

‚Äì and one you would not guess ‚Äì ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt want to know‚Äô / ‚ÄòSong for John‚Äô (explanation below in Memories)

C: Message to Chris:

Very best wishes for this birthday and many more happy ones to come. Thank you for the musical memories over so many years; I am listening to your music now just as I did at 20 when I first heard ‚ÄòSeasons‚Äô; it always makes me so happy.

Memory

I should explain about the ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt want to know‚Äô / ‚ÄòSong for John‚Äô reference above.

I had been to an MC concert at the Nettlebed folk club in Oxfordshire and had bought a CD from the merch desk called ‚ÄòThat‚Äôs the way it goes‚Äô by a young singer called Paul Stewart. That was an earlier ‚Äòstage name‚Äô of Chris before Magna Carta and the CD is mastered from an album in Chris‚Äô private collection. Anyway I was driving home around midnight and had the CD on the player and was enjoying it. It came to track seven called ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt want to know‚Äô and this line suddenly hit me like a punch in the stomach so that I had to stop the car. I hadn‚Äôt known any of the songs up to then but here was ‚Äò.. I saw through your eyes that the snow it lay whiter, that the deeps they were deeper..‚Äô and I knew the rest of the verse before it played ‚Äò‚Ä¶. the rivers were oceans deep rolling in splendour, the trees they were giants that talked to the sky.‚Äô Such a perfect evocation of childhood and that last line being one of my favourite lines in all of Chris‚Äô poetry. I knew I had heard it but couldn‚Äôt place it ‚Äì so annoying and I couldn‚Äôt get the song out of my head.

I got the chance to ask Chris about it at a later concert ‚Äì Grassington I think. I described it and Chris knew it immediately, of course. The Paul Stewart track was an earlier version of ‚ÄòSong for John‚Äô which is on the ‚ÄòPrisoners on the Line‚Äô album. Thanks Chris.

RICHARD TREE, Norfolk

Magna Moments

There are hundreds of Magna Carta stories, ranging from hilarious to tragic.

Chris has always been known for sharing many of those stories from the stage.

Other band members, and those who have worked closely with MC have stories too and, sadly, many of them remain untold.

To redress the balance, it would be nice if some of those people came forward and shared their own experiences of ‚ÄòMagna Moments‚Äô.

Here‚Äôs a little one to be going on with;

Chis wrote a song about the amazing Derrol Adams, a highly talented banjo player who was born in Portland Oregon on the 27th of November 1925. He led an amazing life and it‚Äôs worth reading his biography: https://derrolladams.org/en/biography.html

I believe, and forgive me if I‚Äôm wrong, that he and Chris met at a festival, probably in the 1980s

By that time Derroll was widely known as The Banjo Man, which became the title of the song Chris wrote about him. The hook line of the song, which came at the end of each verse, was ‚ÄúAnd they called him The Banjo Man‚Äù

We regularly played the song so Chris would talk about Derroll‚Äôs amazing charisma and talent before singing it.

One night, in a theatre somewhere in Holland, Chris told the story of Derroll and why he was called the Banjo Man, then launched into the song.

At the end of it, he started singing the line ‚ÄòAnd they called him ‚Äú ‚Ä¶ but then he stopped singing, looked out at the audience, and said

‚ÄúWhat did they call him?‚Äù

The audience fell silent for a couple of seconds, then someone close to the stage offered the answer‚Ä¶.

‚ÄúBenjamin‚Äù

It was a fair answer when you consider the language difference, but I must admit that Chris was slightly taken aback, especially when the rest of the band exploded with the giggles.

Dutch audiences are quick to pick up on the English sense of humour and the whole theatre was soon ringing with laughter, making it a night to remember.

I‚Äôm hoping someone will tell me which theatre it was?

I would like to personally thank the brave soul who came up with the perfect answer, at the perfect time. He was an absolute star!

Derroll died on the 6th of February 2000. Here‚Äôs a you tube video of the Banjo Man in action.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t-q-TQrp-NY

Happy Birthday Chris ‚Ä¶ Where did the years go??

Linda

PHIL GARDNER, Eastbourne:

Our favourite MC song is a difficult choice but it still has to be Seasons and the memories it creates when we hear it.

Special memory

In January 2000 Frances and I decided that a holiday in the Yorkshire Dales would be a great idea. We had never been before and by all accounts it was a beautiful area, added to which it was the home of Magna Carta, so we found a nice cottage and duly booked two weeks in June.

Then in May, Hans Belde sent out an Email advising all friends that a concert might be happening in Yorkshire in June. An exchange of further Emails confirmed that by an amazing coincidence Chris and Linda were to appear at the Nidderdale Festival on Friday 23rd June, the last night of our holiday! Tickets were rapidly obtained from the Tourist Information Centre at Pateley Bridge. Our two weeks in the Dales were superb and gave us an insight into why Chris composes such fantastic songs. It is a beautiful area with superb scenery, wonderful valleys, woodland, villages and loads of character and characters!

But then came Friday 23rd June, that magical day. I was so paranoid that nothing could go wrong that I even rang Pateley Bridge to make sure the concert was still on!

We drove down to Grassington, wandered around the lovely village square and side-streets, sampled the delights of a local restaurant then on to Pateley Bridge.

We had plenty of time to kill so had a walk around to get our bearings including locating the Memorial Hall which was to be the concert venue. Can you imagine, there outside was a white van with it‚Äôs doors open to reveal boxes labelled Magna Carta! Within a minute or so a familiar face appeared and we walked across and introduced ourselves to Chris. This was a magical moment, as we met for the first time, someone whose music had been an integral part of our lives. We spoke briefly to Chris and Linda then left them to get on with setting up.

That night we were in heaven. The concert was brilliant, a mix of old favourites, such as Airport Song, Sea and Sand, Time For The Leaving, Putting It Back Together plus many newer numbers many of which we had never heard. Both Chris and Linda‚Äôs voices were superb, accompanied by their own brilliant guitar work and some excellent musicians.

All too soon the concert came to end but not before the audience brought the house down as they demanded an encore. We stayed behind to congratulate them on a wonderful evening that meant so much to us and we were able to celebrate 30 years of living with Magna Carta in the most memorable way.

After that we have managed to see MC in concert at various locations ‚Äì Saul Canal festival in Gloucestershire, concerts in Suffolk, Lincolnshire, Essex, West Sussex and we managed to get to Amsterdam for the 40th anniversary concert at Le Carre Theatre. In April 2002 I organised a concert for them in Eastbourne and Chris and Linda stayed with us, Chris and I stayed up until the early hours talking about their music and life!!!!

Thanks again Chris for some amazing memories.

This is the programme for the 1970 Summer Ball for Royal Holloway College in Egham, Surrey. This was the first time that we saw Magna Carta in concert. They performed at 5.30 am on a beautiful summer‚Äôs morning. Among the songs that they sang was Seasons. We were mesmerised and at the end were in tears. We were hooked from that moment on and 54 years later their music is still part of our lives! By coincidence, the date of the Summer Ball, was exactly one year to the day, before we were married on 19th June 1971!

Happy 82nd Birthday Chris and thank you for creating such amazing music and giving us so many wonderful musical memories

Memories of Magna Carta

The first time I saw Magna Carta in concert was in 1971 in De Harmonie in my hometown Leeuwarden. They were part of a show with Ramses Shaffy, Liesbeth List en The Louis van Dijk trio. I knew the band from their records. The lineup was: Chris Simpson, Glenn Stuart and Davey Johnstone. I remember high harmony voices by Chris and Glenn and virtuoso guitar playing by Chris and Davey. All this thru Orange equipment. It was a show with different styles of music: the songs of Shaffy and List in Dutch (a bit like the French Chansons), jazzlike music by Louis van Dijk and the folk oriented music by Magna Carta. At the end of of the progam Liesbeth sang songs written by Mikis Theodorakis, accompagnied by Magna Carta.

In 1977 I saw them again. In that year I made a record called ‚ÄúRambling round‚Äù under the name of Pete Cox, that was released by Philips, the same company that sold Magna Carta albums. For promotion purposes I was asked to do some shows as a support act for MC, mostly in the north of Holland. I was also a support act for groups like Camel and The Streetwalkers but then the audience would mostly yell and scream to get me and my guitar off the stage as quick as possible. But with Magna Carta it was very different: people were listening and interested in what I did and so were the guys of MC. At that time the lineup of the band was: Chris, Tom Hoy and Nigel Portman-Smith.

One time, I think it was in Heerenveen, they asked me to come and play with them in two encores: When will I be loved and Goodnight Irene. Exciting!

The next time they came to Holland I also did some support shows. The lineup of MC had changed: Chris,Tom, on bass there was Lee Abbott and on drums Pick Withers (later to be in Dire Staits). I remember a show when I started playing the Buddy Holly song Peggy Sue and Pick jumped behind his drums to play with me. Later he said to me: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs one of my favorite songs!‚Äù.

The last time I played with them was in 1982 in Deinum. MC was a four piece: drums, bass and two guitars with a JJ Cale flavor. I was also with a band with the same lineup. In the years that followed I did not go to any of their shows but I had occasionaly contact with Chris by email. I had the intention to see them on their final farewell tour but due to illness I could not come.
